case_name: Petitioner v. State of Tamil Nadu and Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 284 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 284 of 1972. Under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petitioner seeks mandamus to withdraw and cancel order dated 27 June 1972 and repost as Chief Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in this writ petition under Article 32 of the Constitution asks for a mandamus or any other appropriate writ, direction or order directing the respondents to withdraw and cancel the order dated 27 June, 1972.

facts.text: Petitioner is a member of the Indian Administrative Service in the cadre of the State of Tamil Nadu.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are the State of Tamil Nadu and the Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu. The petitioner is a member of the Indian Administrative Service in the cadre of the State of Tamil Nadu.

facts.text: Petitioner confirmed in Selection Grade of IAS with effect from 22 May 1961 on 2 August 1968.

anchor.surface_text: On 2 August, 1968 the petitioner was companyfirmed in the Selection Grade of the Indian Administrative Service with effect from 22 May, 1961.

facts.text: There were 8 Selection Grade posts in Tamil Nadu; petitioner was No. 4 in the list.

anchor.surface_text: There were 8 Selection Grade posts in the State of Tamil Nadu. The petitioner was No. 4 in that list.

facts.text: Petitioner posted as Additional Chief Secretary on 11 July 1969; post temporarily created for one year.

anchor.surface_text: On 11 July, 1969 the petitioner was posted to act as Additional Chief Secretary- On 11 July, 1969 the post of Additional Chief Secretary was temproraily created in the grade of Chief, Secretary for one year.

facts.text: State Government deemed posts of Chief Secretary, Additional Chief Secretary, and First Member Board of Revenue interchangeable selection posts.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government further directed that, the post of Chief Secretary to Government, Additional Chief Secretary to Government and the First Member, Board of Revenue were deemed to be in the same category and they were inter- changeable selection posts.

facts.text: Central Government on 26 September 1969 stated Additional Chief Secretary not a cadre post and should not dilute status of Chief Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India by a letter dated 26 September, 1969 stated that the status of Chief Secretary as the head of the Secretariat Organisation in the State should remain unquestioned.

facts.text: Petitioner posted to act as Chief Secretary on 13 November 1969 vice C.A. Ramakrishnan on refused leave from 14 November 1969.

anchor.surface_text: On 13 November, 1969 the petitioner was posted to act as Chief Secretary to Government with effect from the afternoon of 13 November, 1969 vice C.A. Ramakrishnan whose date of superannuation was. 14 November, 1969

facts.text: Ramakrishnan granted refused leave for four months from 14 November 1969; retired 14 March 1970.

anchor.surface_text: When Ramakrishnan went on refused leave for four months from 14 November, 1969 there was numbersubstantive vacancy in the post of Chief Secretary.

facts.text: Court finds petitioner was not substantively appointed to Chief Secretary post; only temporary/officiating.

anchor.surface_text: He was number appointed substantively to the post of Chief Secretary. The fact that the petitioner was number appointed substantively to the post of Chief Secretary

facts.text: Petitioner appointed Deputy Chairman State Planning Commission on 7 April 1971, temporary post for one year.

anchor.surface_text: On 7 April, 1971 the petitioner was appointed Deputy Chairman. of the State Planning Commission. That post was created temporarily for a period of one year

facts.text: Petitioner went on leave from 13 April 1971 to 5 June 1972; did not join Deputy Chairman post.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner went on leave from 13 April, 1971 to 5 June, 1972. When the petitioner was on leave Raja Ram, the First Member, Board of Revenue

facts.text: On 6 June 1972, petitioner reposted as Deputy Chairman on Rs. 3500/- pm; did not join.

anchor.surface_text: On 6 June, 1972 the petitioner returned from leave. He was again. posted as Deputy Chairman, State. Planning Commission on a salary of Rs. 3500/- per month.

facts.text: Order dated 27 June 1972 created temporary post of Officer on Special Duty in grade of Chief Secretary; petitioner appointed thereto.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated 27 June, 1972 the Government of Tamil Nadu accorded sanction to the creation of a temporary post of Officer on Special Duty in the grade of Chief Secretary

facts.text: Petition filed in July 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in the month of July, 1972 filed this petition.

facts.text: Court holds posts of Deputy Chairman and Officer on Special Duty equivalent in status and responsibility to Chief Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: The position of the Deputy Chairman is equal in status and responsibility to the duties of, the Chief Secretary.

facts.text: Petitioner's allegations of mala fides by Chief Minister rejected by court.

anchor.surface_text: The entire affidavit evidence establishes beyond any measure of doubt that the petitioners allegations imputing malafides against the Chief Minister are baseless.

facts.text: Petition dismissed; each party bears own costs.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons the companytentions of the petitioner. fail. The. petition is dismissed. Each party will pay and bear its own companyts.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by A.N. Ray, C.J.; separate opinion by P.N. Bhagwati, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of,, A. N. RAY , C.J. and D. G. PALEKAR J. was delivered by RAY, C.J. A separate opinion of Y. V. CHANDRACHUD, P. N. BHAGWATI and V. R. KRISHNA IYER, JJ. was given by BHAGWATI, J.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges creation of Officer on Special Duty post and transfer mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: Fourth, the creation of the post as well as the appointment and transfer of the petitioner to the post is malafide.

facts.text: Ramakrishnan held lien on Chief Secretary post until 14 March 1970 due to refused leave.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, Ramakrishnan held lien on his post until 14 March, 1970.

facts.text: State Planning Commission constituted on 25 May 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The State planning Commission was in the meantime companystituted on 25th May, 1971

holdings.text: The petitioner was not substantively appointed to the post of Chief Secretary; the appointment was temporary to act during refused leave.

anchor.surface_text: He was number appointed substantively to the post of Chief Secretary. The fact that the petitioner was number appointed substantively to the post of Chief Secretary

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gazette notification specifies 'to act as'; no confirmation order passed; Ramakrishnan retained lien until end of refused leave on 14 March 1970 per pre-Constitution FRs and Art 314.

holdings.text: Posts of Deputy Chairman State Planning Commission and Officer on Special Duty are valid temporary additions under proviso to Rule 4(2) IAS Cadre Rules carrying duties and responsibilities of like nature to cadre posts without altering cadre strength.

anchor.surface_text: The aforementioned second proviso to Rule 4 2  of the Cadre Rules does number companyfer any power on the State Government to alter the strength and companyposition of, the cadre. If such power were companyferred on the State examination of the strength and companyposition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso allows State to add temporary posts for specified periods; posts do not become cadre posts or increase strength; duties detailed as high level policy and revenue functions.

holdings.text: Declaration under Rule 9 IAS Pay Rules that posts are equivalent in status and responsibility to cadre posts is desirable but not mandatory if reasons recorded; substance shows equivalence.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-rule 4 of rule 9 states that where equation of posts is number possible the State Government or the Central Government may, for sufficient reasons to be recorded in writing appoint a member of a service to such a post without making a declaration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-rule 9(4) permits appointment without declaration if reasons recorded; court examines pay, duties, importance; finds equivalence in substance over form.

holdings.text: Posts of Deputy Chairman and Officer on Special Duty are equal in status and responsibility to Chief Secretary; transfer does not constitute hostile discrimination under Articles 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: The position of the Deputy Chairman is equal in status and responsibility to the duties of, the Chief Secretary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pay scale Rs 3500 pm same as Chief Secretary; duties of planning, tax rationalisation require high calibre equivalent to Chief Secretary; no reduction in rank.

holdings.text: Creation of posts and transfer of petitioner not mala fide; allegations against Chief Minister baseless.

anchor.surface_text: The entire affidavit evidence establishes beyond any measure of doubt that the petitioners allegations imputing malafides against the Chief Minister are baseless.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit evidence refutes specific allegations; no contemporaneous records or protests by petitioner; actions accepted petitioner's prior advice; post-election normalcy.

holdings.text: No violation of Fundamental Rule 15; posts carry pay not less than lien post in selection grade.

anchor.surface_text: Fundamental Rule, 15 provides that numberGovernment servant can be, transferred substantively to or appointed to officiate in a post carrying less pay than the pay of the permanent post on Which holds a lien

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's lien in selection grade Rs 1800-2000; new posts Rs 3500 pm higher; FR15 protects against lower pay posts.

holdings.text: Petition dismissed; contentions fail; parties bear own costs.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons the companytentions of the petitioner. fail. The. petition is dismissed. Each party will pay and bear its own companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All grounds rejected; no fundamental rights violation under Art 32.

anchor.surface_text: The petition is dismissed. Each party will pay and bear its own costs.
